review.title: A Linked Data Scalability Challenge: Concept Reuse Leads to Semantic Decay
review.abstract: The increasing amount of available Linked Data resources is laying the foundations for more advanced Semantic Web applications. One of their main limitations, however, remains the general low level of data quality. In this paper we focus on a measure of quality which is negatively affected by the increase of the available resources. We propose a measure of semantic richness of Linked Data concepts and we demonstrate our hypothesis that the more a concept is reused, the less semantically rich it becomes. This is a significant scalability issue, as one of the core aspects of Linked Data is the propagation of semantic information on the Web by reusing common terms. We prove our hypothesis with respect to our measure of semantic richness and we validate our model empirically. Finally, we suggest possible future directions to address this scalability problem.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: In recent years, we have seen a constant increase in available data resources. As the problem of data availability gradually diminishes, data quality remains one of the most important limiting factors for linked data applications. At the root of this problem lies the openness of linked data approaches. [10] We define our measures of semantic reach as the amount of facts we can derive from a concept, namely the semantic reach of linked data views. [10] We define our measures of semantic reach as the sum of the facts we expect to conclude from the re-use of the data.

sections.heading: 2. PROBLEM DEFINITION
sections.text: We define a measurement of semantic wealth as a function that represents a concept α, such as foaf: Person2, and a linked data graph S, such as the DBpedia graph [1], and returns a positive real number, which quantifies the amount of information conveyed by the concept α within the graph S. In other words, it is a measure of how many facts we can expect to infer from the instances of this concept found in the graph. If we quantify (α, S1) > the amount of information, then we know that an entity of type α contains more facts in the context of the graph S1 than S2.In creating such a measurement it is important to take scalability and robustness into account, as there are large differences in the size and quality of linked data resources. It should be possible to calculate this measurement effectively across large amounts of linked data. Furthermore, this measurement should be applicable to any arbitrary data set, even if applicable.

sections.heading: 3. BACKGROUND
sections.text: The concept of information content (IC) has been proposed to measure the informaticity of concepts within a taxonomy in the field of information theory [11]. This measurement has proved effective not only in terms of concepts, but also in measuring the informaticity of resources and relationships within a knowledge base [8]. The IC of a concept α within a knowledge base is defined as IC (α) = − log (α), where p (α) is the probability of an entity belonging to the concept α. One limitation of the applicability of this measurement is that the probability p (α) could not be meaningful when taking domain-specific datasets into account. Several existing datasets contain only cases of type foaf: Person. The IC of this concept calculated using these datasets will always be zero (foaf: 1). The IC measurement would not distinguish between the different datasets, although they might have a different setical interpretation of the concept.

sections.heading: 4. THE SEMANTIC RICHNESS MEASURE
sections.text: Considering a concept α, such as foaf: Person, we define a measure of its semantic wealth G, which quantifies the amount of information conveyed by the concept. In contrast to IC-based metrics, our measure is not proportional to the probability of an entity being a member of the concept. However, this probability cannot be reliably estimated for linked data due to its open nature and partial observation capability. In evaluating the semantic wealth of a concept, we only assume the availability of a representative subset of this concept obtained from a finite number of sources. Taxonomic information about the concept is not required. Our measurement of semantic wealth G is defined as a function of the number of facts we can derive from its instances and their probability to be correct. These facts are presented, for example, as graphs showing persons with a date of birth: {? Person a foaf: Person foaf: Birthday?

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: Once we have defined our model for measuring semantic wealth, we perform an empirical validation of this metric and our hypothesis. This experimental evaluation, carried out over several large datasets, also provides evidence of the scalability of our metric. These experiments are based on the implementation of a system that can select units from a dataset and calculate the semantic wealth of a concept within the dataset.

sections.heading: 5.1 Validation of the Semantic Measure
sections.text: Our approach uses a numerical measure of the semantic wealth of a concept using Equation 4. But how well does this measure actually capture the concept of semantic wealth? We evaluate this measure based on the intuition that concepts are, on average, less semantically rich than their subconcepts. A similar property is also found in the IC measure, since the IC of a concept is by definition always inferior or equal to or equal to the IC of its subconcepts.6 To reduce computational complexity, we have evaluated how well our measure of this intuition matches the concepts of DBpedia ontology 5 by calculating the semantic wealth of the entities of each concept.6 To reduce computational complexity, all concepts with over 1000 entities have been replaced by a randomly sampled set of 1000 entities. Also, we only consider simple graph patterns containing a single threefold. Specifically, we consider patterns as pairs < p > concepts that coincide with a concept that is subordinated.

The list of endpoints used to access the datasets is in Table 1. From each endpoint, we have extracted information about 1000 randomly selected entities. For each dataset, we have calculated its semantic wealth in different states. Starting from the semantic wealth of the original dataset, we have recalculated this measure after adding more and more entities from the other datasets. Figure 2 shows the progressive decay of semantic wealth as we add new entities of the same type from other sources. The semantic wealth of each dataset is quickly converted to a value significantly worse than the average measurement.

sections.heading: 6. RETAINING SEMANTIC RICHNESS
sections.text: Since linked data does not allow negation, it is not possible to prevent an entity from becoming a member of a concept. However, it is possible to predict the effect that adding an entity to a dataset would have on the semantic richness of a concept. We define E as the set of patterns that match an entity. The degree of typicity of an entity in relation to a concept α can then be defined, which means that the inclusion of an entity in a concept would lead to a reduction of its semantic richness if it is the set of frequent patterns of α. In the face of two entities and this, we can say that this is more typical than "if."

sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This measure differs from earlier semantic measures, such as information content, in that it is intended to compare the difference in the semantic richness of the same concept between different data sets. We have confirmed this measure in relation to the ontology of DBpedia by showing that it captures the expected intuition that sub-concepts are on average more semantic than their superconcepts. We have used the mathematical formulation of this measure to prove our hypothesis that the more a concept is reused, the less semantically rich it becomes. To verify the extent of this problem, we compared the semantic richness of the foaf concept: person from ten different existing data sets. Our preliminary results show that the semantic richness of a concept rapidly decreases when entities of several data sets are merged.

referenceMentions.context: Following a number-of-features approach [10], we define our measure of semantic richness as the amount of facts that we can expect to infer from a concept.
Web-scale reuse of semantic formalisations, such as concepts and relations, is an essential aspect of Linked Data [2].

A notable example is the owl:sameAs relation, originally intended to represent strict equality between two entities, which is frequently misused to represent a wide range of weaker similarity relations [5].
We define a measure of semantic richness Γ as a function that takes a concept α, such as foaf:Person and a Linked Data graph S, such as the DBpedia graph [1], and returns a positive real number.
The notion of Information Content (IC) has been proposed to measure the informativeness of concepts within a taxonomy in the field of Information Theory [11].
This measure has been shown to be effective not only with respect to concepts, but also to measure the informativeness of resources and relations within a knowledge base [8].
In the field of Cognitive Neuroscience several measures of semantic richness have been proposed [10].
The main advantages of Inductive Learning approaches are scalability and robustness to errors and uncertainty [4].
Schema information can be inferred from a knowledge base by considering the frequency of certain patterns in the data, such as the common properties shared by the entities of the same type [3].
For example, it is possible to evaluate how well a Linked Data graph matches a set of schema rules by using SPARQL query patterns [7].
Several approaches have been proposed to represent contextual information about Linked Data, in particular with respect to Provenance [9].
Unlike IC-based measures [6], our measure is not proportional to the probability of an entity being a member of the concept.
